Herbert Saito Biography

  1. Home

  2. Explore Stories

  3. Biography

Atsushi Saito

Themes

War & Military
Community
Social Justice & Activism

Biography

Atsushi “Herbert” Saito was a Japanese American student who attended Miami University from 1940 to 1943. Born on April 21st, 1921 in Kapehu, Hawaii to parents Shinichi Saito and Onao Kurisu Saito, he grew up in North Hilo, Hawaii where both of his parents worked at a sugar cane plantation. Saito graduated from Hilo High School in 1939, spending a year working in the county clerk’s office before enrolling at Miami as a Liberal Arts major on a pre-law track in the fall of 1940.

During his time at Miami, Herbert was involved in a number of student organizations. He served as president of the Cosmopolitan Club— an international club that welcomed students of diverse backgrounds— and was a member of the Speakers Bureau, the Association of Miami Independents, Tau Kappa Alpha fraternity, and Les Politiques, a club for those interested in political science. Selected to participate in the Fisk Public Speaking Contest all three years he attended Miami, he placed third his freshman and sophomore years and second his senior year. Several of his speeches focused on his experiences growing up in the then-Hawaii Territory— in addition to public speaking opportunities, he also vocalized his support for Hawaiian statehood in publications like The Miami Student. When U.S. involvement in World War II created an increased need for Japanese translators, Saito volunteered to teach a non-credit Japanese course to assist his peers in learning the language. He taught the course for two years. He was one of many Miami students during the war years who, as part of a larger project conducted by history professor Dr. William E. Smith, documented both their daily campus lives and perceptions of the war through diary entries. Herbert graduated in the spring of 1943 and enlisted in the military that July, where he served as a linguist in the U.S. Army Air Force.

Following his return from war, Saito began teaching back home on Hilo, first at Kohala High School and then at Konawaena High School, where he would eventually retire from. An English teacher, he served as an advisor to a number of different extracurricular clubs, including the Kona Junior Rifle Club and the Kona Junior Young Buddhist Association. He married Ayoka “Ethel” Imai in 1950— the couple had three daughters together, Gloria, Darlene, and Jeanne. Herbert remained active in the Hilo community throughout his life, serving as a Sunday school teacher at his Honwanji Buddhist temple, commander of Post 20 of the American Legion, and secretary for the Kona Invitational Softball League.

Herbert Saito passed away on June 12th, 1993 at the age of seventy-two.

Credits

Written by Laurel Myers, (4, History & American Studies, 2023)
